snippet: Officials insisted the guidelines were not a new policy — merely a clarification of existing rules — but Israel quickly denounced the move as a form of discrimination.
abstract: Tension between European Union and Israel increases yet again after EU votes to have labels saying 'made in settlements' affixed to some goods produced on land seized during 1967 conflict; Israel fears labels will allow targeting of businesses, which could open gates to greater boycotting and economic woes.

byline.original: By JODI RUDOREN and SEWELL CHAN
byline.contributor: Jodi Rudoren reported from Jerusalem, and Sewell Chan from London. Irit Pazner Garshowitz contributed reporting from Jerusalem.

lead_paragraph: Officials insisted the guidelines were not a new policy — merely a clarification of existing rules — but Israel quickly denounced the move as a form of discrimination.

headline.main: E.U. Move to Label Israeli Settlement Goods Strains Ties
headline.print_headline: E.U. Move Fans Fear of Boycott Aimed at Israel
